it's good to know your widest aperture
your widest aperture is normally around
F 2.8 F 3.4 something like that that'll
be your widest aperture now that's when
you get your softest focus on your food
as you close down that aperture that's
when you went to get the most in focus
now you have to relate speed to that
ultimately you have to get the same
amount of light from your subject onto
your Bank sensor so the wider the
aperture the faster the speed will be
the smaller the aperture the slower the
speed will be I know that I want this
soft and gooey and romantic but just so
I can explain depth of field to you I'm
going to shoot it wide open at 2.8 so
I'll shoot one shot at 2.8 wide open and
that's at a twentieth of a second now if
I close my aperture to just to show you
this is I wouldn't shoot it this way but
just to show you - 8 f8 or even f9 let's
do two f9 now because I'd close the
aperture I need to open the speed to
allow more light in so I'm going to
shoot it I shot the first one at 20th of
a second I'm going to shoot this one at
half a second almost half a second again
little bit of light very steady at half
second so here we have the two shots
I've just taken first shot shot at 2.8 a
twentieth of a second focus as I said on
the little grain of the toast the drip
coming out of the egg the goo coming out
of the egg everything's very soft very
romantic it's a bit of focus on the
spoon then the one I shot just to show
you where I closed the
picture but opens the speed so more like
being let in through the small aperture
and that's that so you can see still are
areas that we wanted in focus but what's
happened is the focus has been spread
down the shot so now the whole of the
piece of toast is in focus the little
pepper pot is in focus the whole of the
top of the egg but what's happened as
well is more of the background which to
me is distracting in this case not
always but in this case it is
distracting has become more focused
